results.title: The Dolphin kick
results.creator_credit: Coronet Instructional Films and Jorhal Pictures
results.brief_description: A swimmer, an underwater camera, and carefully devised teaching demonstrations introduce the new swimming technique known as the dolphin or fishtail kick. Analysing the body movements used in this technique, the film stresses the importance of practice for mastery of this efficient, speedy kick. From this kick, the Butterfly Stroke was developed.

results.title: Don't let our children die
results.brief_description: Anne Deveson discusses both the 1973, and, at the time of the making of the film, the current drought of 1975 in Ethiopia. Shows volunteer and professional relief workers and army and government officials involved in famine relief. Both the victims and the rehabilitation attempts are shown against a background of physical and political conditions. Other credits: “made by Ossie Emery, Betti Wood, Don Clay, John Morrow and many others”.

results.title: Don't label me
results.creator_credit: Douglas Leiterman, Richard Ballentine and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Examines the subject of neutralism, or non-alignment, as preached and practised by Dr. Cheddi Jagan, Prime Minister of the former colony of British Guiana, now emerging from colonization, who admires Castro, but also pleads, “Don’t try to pin any labels on me!”

results.title: Don't be a dummy
results.creator_credit: Joe Mendoza, Oswald Skilbeck, Central Electric Authority and Verity Films
results.brief_description: Details of safety precautions to be taken in certain operations and maintenance work associated with electricity generating stations, the underlying principle being the permit-to-work. Deals with such things as towing ropes, coal bunkers, and conveyors, boiler blow-down valves, and jib and overhead cranes and trucks.

results.title: Don't be a carrier
results.creator_credit: Ann Millard, Jack Keane, Australian Agricultural Council and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: Illustrates how plant pests and diseases are spread by the carelessness of travellers carrying fruit, vegetables and plants across State borders. Strict quarantine regulations have been enforced to prevent the spread of disease to the Murray and Barossa Valleys. In South Australia, free of Black Spot and Codlin Moth, the importation of apples from interstate or overseas is prohibited. In recent years, Fruit Fly has been introduced into Victoria and South Australia necessitating costly spraying and destruction of fruit in infected areas, an undertaking which is the result of carelessness of a few individuals in the community.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ann Millard, Jack Keane, Australian Agricultural Council and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture

results.title: Donald's fire survival plan
results.creator_credit: Les Clark, Ken Peterson and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: The need for a fire survival plan in the home. Every day over 1500 homes burn, and 18 lives are lost, one third of them children. Schools, industrial plants and public buildings practise proper procedures, why not homes? Donald Duck works out a plan to protect his family in case of fire.

results.title: Donald's better self
results.creator_credit: Jack King, Walt Disney and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Donald Duck has two sides to his character. On the one hand, his good self strives to do the right thing, but his bad self usually wins. Donald sleeps late in the morning, and it takes his better self to make him dress and start off the school. On the way to school his bad self entices him to play truant.

results.title: Donald in Mathmagic land
results.creator_credit: Hamilton Luske, Walt Disney and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Donald Duck participates in a remarkable adventure and learns that music, architecture, art and science are all based on mathematical principles. Tracing the history and development of these principles, we find the Arabs responsible for our present numbers and algebra; Egypt the source of geometric theories, the pyramids remaining as a monument to their knowledge of the triangle; and to the Greeks Pythagoras we owe our musical scale.
